source.name: City of San Diego Environmental Services
source.notes: Based on City of San Diego recycling and organic waste (SB 1383) guidelines. Styrofoam packaging is accepted in blue bin. Green bin organic program includes food scraps and food-soiled paper.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: San Diego blue bin is collected bi-weekly
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still in them

materials.name: Plastic jugs
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Large rigid plastic jugs accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include jugs with product still in them

materials.name: Plastic tubs and trays
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Rigid plastic food containers, jugs, tubs, and trays all accepted
commonMistakes: No soft/flexible plastic film

materials.name: Plastic pots, buckets, and toys
instructions: Empty
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: San Diego accepts rigid plastics including pots, buckets, and toys
commonMistakes: No flexible plastics or film
Remove dirt from flower pots

materials.name: Styrofoam packaging
instructions: Place clean styrofoam packaging in blue recycling bin
Remove tape, labels, and food residue
Break into pieces that fit in the bin
notes: San Diego uniquely accepts styrofoam packaging in the blue bin!
This is unusual; most cities do not accept styrofoam
commonMistakes: Must be clean and free of food residue
Foam peanuts should be bagged so they don't blow away

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Glass is accepted curbside in San Diego's blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass; wrap and trash it
Don't include ceramics, mirrors, or window glass

materials.name: Aluminum cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue

materials.name: Steel / tin cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them

materials.name: Metal containers
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: All metal containers accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include aerosol cans that aren't fully empty

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Flatten all boxes
Remove packing materials
Place in or beside blue recycling bin
notes: Bi-weekly collection; make sure boxes fit near the bin
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease
Remove styrofoam inserts

materials.name: Paper and newspaper
instructions: Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Most clean dry paper is recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels or tissues
Don't bag paper in plastic bags

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place shredded paper in a paper bag, then seal the bag
Place the sealed paper bag in blue recycling bin
notes: San Diego accepts shredded paper if contained in a paper bag
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper in the bin; it blows away and jams equipment
examples: Shredded documents in a paper bag

materials.name: Drink cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Cartons accepted in San Diego recycling
commonMistakes: Don't crush; leave them as-is

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Non-empty aerosols are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Clean off food residue
Ball up and place in blue recycling bin
notes: Only clean aluminum foil is recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't recycle heavily soiled foil

materials.name: Food scraps
instructions: Place in green bin
All food scraps accepted: fruit, vegetables, cooked meat, bones, eggshells, grains
No plastic bags; use paper bags or go loose
notes: Green bin is collected weekly
SB 1383 requires organic waste diversion in California
commonMistakes: Don't put food scraps in black trash bin
Don't use plastic bags in green bin

materials.name: Fruit / fruit scraps
instructions: Place in green bin
All fruit and fruit scraps accepted
notes: California SB 1383 requires food scrap composting
commonMistakes: Don't put in black trash bin

materials.name: Vegetables / vegetable scraps
instructions: Place in green bin
notes: All vegetables accepted in green bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in black trash bin

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Place in green bin
Cooked meat, raw meat, bones all accepted
notes: San Diego's green bin accepts all meat and bones per SB 1383
commonMistakes: Don't put in black trash bin

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Place dairy products in green bin
Pour expired milk down drain; compost the residue
notes: Dairy accepted in green bin
commonMistakes: Rinse and recycle the container separately in blue bin

materials.name: Bread and grains
instructions: Place in green bin
notes: All grain products accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put in black trash bin

materials.name: Eggs / eggshells
instructions: Place eggshells in green bin
notes: Eggshells add calcium to compost
commonMistakes: Crush shells for faster breakdown

materials.name: Coffee grounds / coffee filters
instructions: Coffee grounds and paper filters: green bin
notes: Paper coffee filters are accepted with grounds
commonMistakes: Remove any plastic components

materials.name: Tea bags
instructions: Tea bags go in black trash bin
Most tea bags contain plastic sealing and are NOT accepted in the green bin
notes: San Diego specifically notes tea bags are NOT accepted in the green bin due to plastic sealing
Loose tea leaves can go in the green bin
commonMistakes: Don't put tea bags in the green bin; they contain plastic

materials.name: Food-soiled paper
instructions: Place in green bin
Paper towels, napkins, newspaper, paper bags, coffee filters all accepted when food-soiled
notes: Food-soiled paper is a key component of San Diego's green bin program
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled paper in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Place in green bin
Grass, leaves, branches, and untreated wood accepted
Cut branches to fit in the bin
notes: Green bin collected weekly
commonMistakes: Don't bag yard waste in plastic bags
Don't include treated or painted wood

materials.name: Untreated wood
instructions: Place small untreated wood pieces in green bin
notes: Only untreated, unpainted wood accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include painted, stained, or pressure-treated wood

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Do NOT put in blue recycling bin or green bin
Take to grocery store drop-off for recycling
Otherwise place in black trash bin
notes: Plastic bags jam recycling machinery
No plastic bags in ANY bin
commonMistakes: Never bag recyclables in plastic bags
Don't put any film plastic in the blue bin

materials.name: Candy wrapper
instructions: Place in black trash bin
notes: Metallized plastic film is not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling or compost

materials.name: Chip bag
instructions: Place in black trash bin
notes: Metallized plastic film is not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Most lined paper cups: black trash bin
Plastic lids: blue recycling bin
Paper sleeve: blue recycling bin
notes: The plastic/wax lining prevents paper cup recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put lined cups in recycling

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Place in black trash bin
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Never put diapers in green or blue bins

materials.name: Receipts
instructions: Place in black trash bin
Thermal paper contains BPA
notes: Thermal receipts contaminate recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do not put in trash or recycling
Take to a San Diego household hazardous waste facility
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries
notes: San Diego has a permanent HHW facility
commonMistakes: Don't throw batteries in trash
Don't put in blue bin

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to City of San Diego Environmental Services drop-off
Best Buy also accepts e-waste
Delete personal data before disposal
notes: California law prohibits e-waste in trash
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in trash or recycling

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to San Diego household hazardous waste facility
Latex paint: can also dry out with kitty litter and trash
Oil-based paint: must go to hazardous waste
notes: San Diego has a permanent HHW facility at Miramar
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Take to San Diego HHW facility or auto parts store
AutoZone and O'Reilly accept used oil
notes: Most auto parts stores accept oil for free
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to a San Diego drug take-back location
Many pharmacies participate in take-back programs
If no drop-off: mix with coffee grounds, seal, and trash
notes: DEA hosts periodic National Prescription Drug Take Back events
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or thrift stores
Textile recycling bins available at various locations
notes: Even worn-out textiles can be recycled at textile bins
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in curbside recycling

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent: take to HHW facility or Home Depot/Lowe's
LED bulbs: e-waste recycling
Incandescent: wrap and place in black trash bin
notes: CFL bulbs contain mercury
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL bulbs in trash

materials.name: Cooking oil / grease
instructions: Collect in a sealed container
Take to San Diego HHW facility
Never pour down the drain
notes: Grease causes sewer blockages
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink or storm drains

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to San Diego HHW facility
Never put in trash or recycling
notes: Pressurized containers are fire risks
commonMistakes: Never puncture

materials.name: Needles / sharps
instructions: Place in FDA-cleared sharps container
Take to San Diego HHW facility or participating pharmacy
notes: California law requires proper sharps disposal
commonMistakes: Never put in recycling or loose in trash

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Schedule a bulky item pickup with San Diego Environmental Services
Or take to Miramar Landfill
notes: San Diego offers bulk item pickup
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Large / bulk items
instructions: Schedule bulk pickup through San Diego 311
Place at curb on scheduled day
notes: San Diego provides bulk item collection by appointment
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Chargers and cables
instructions: Take to Best Buy or e-waste drop-off
Do NOT put in blue recycling bin
notes: Cables tangle in recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Never put cables in curbside recycling

materials.name: Smartphone / phone
instructions: Factory reset first
Trade in at carrier stores or Apple/Samsung
Take to Best Buy for free recycling
notes: California law prohibits e-waste in trash
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in black trash bin
Do NOT compost pet waste
notes: Pet waste contains harmful bacteria
commonMistakes: Never put pet waste in the green bin

materials.name: Fast food wrapper
instructions: Food-soiled fast food wrappers: green bin
Clean paper wrappers: blue recycling bin
notes: Food-soiled paper accepted in San Diego green bin
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy wrappers in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Books
instructions: Donate if in good condition
If damaged, recycle paper pages in blue bin
Remove hardcover bindings with glossy laminate (trash them)
notes: Donating is always better than recycling
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in trash

materials.name: Bubble wrap / packing materials
instructions: Place in black trash bin
Or drop off at store film recycling collection
notes: Plastic film jams recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Wax paper / parchment paper
instructions: Place in green bin
notes: Wax-coated paper is compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Snacks and candy (food)
instructions: The food: green bin
The wrapper: black trash bin
notes: Separate food from wrapper
commonMistakes: Don't put wrappers in green bin

materials.name: Condiments and sauces
instructions: The sauce: green bin
The bottle: rinse and put in blue recycling bin
notes: Separate container from contents
commonMistakes: Don't recycle bottles with sauce still in them

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to tire retailer or Miramar Landfill
Most shops accept old tires when you buy new ones
notes: Illegal to dump tires
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally

materials.name: Mirrors
instructions: Wrap carefully and place in black trash bin
notes: Metallic coating prevents glass recycling
commonMistakes: Never put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Toothbrush
instructions: Place in black trash bin
notes: Mixed plastic; not recyclable curbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Makeup / cosmetics
instructions: Most containers go in black trash bin
Clean empty rigid plastic containers may be recyclable
notes: Check brand take-back programs
commonMistakes: Small items fall through sorting screens

materials.name: Plastic utensils / straws
instructions: Place in black trash bin
notes: Too small for recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Ink / toner cartridges
instructions: Return to Staples or Office Depot
Manufacturers offer mail-back programs
notes: Some stores give credit for returns
commonMistakes: Don't throw in trash

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes
instructions: Take to San Diego HHW facility
Home Depot and Lowe's also accept them
notes: Contains mercury; handle carefully
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash
Don't break them

materials.name: Hangers
instructions: Wire hangers: return to dry cleaner
Plastic hangers: black trash bin
notes: Hangers jam sorting equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put hangers in blue recycling bin

recycle: Plastic bottles, jugs, tubs, trays, pots, buckets, and toys (rigid plastics)
Aluminum and steel cans, metal containers
Shredded paper (in a sealed paper bag)
compost: Food scraps (fruit, vegetables, cooked meat, bones, eggshells, grains)
Food-soiled paper (paper towels, napkins, newspaper, paper bags, coffee filters)
Yard waste (grass, leaves, branches, untreated wood)

tips: Styrofoam packaging IS accepted in the blue recycling bin in San Diego!
Blue recycling bin is collected bi-weekly; green bin is weekly
Tea bags are NOT accepted in the green bin due to plastic sealing; loose tea leaves are OK
Shredded paper must go in a sealed paper bag before placing in blue bin
No plastic bags in ANY bin
Food-soiled paper goes in the green bin, not the blue bin
SB 1383 requires all food scraps and food-soiled paper in the green bin
